newsitem.title: USA: East Coast refineries eye hurricane, no action yet.
newsitem.headline: East Coast refineries eye hurricane, no action yet.

text.p: Several U.S. East Coast refineries said Wednesday they were monitoring Hurricane Fran but have not yet taken any measures against the powerful storm churning off Charleston, S.C.
"It's still very early to take measures but we are watching it," said Michael Karlovich, spokesman for Tosco Corp's 230,000 barrel per day refinery in Linden, N.J.
As of 1100 EDT, Hurricane Fran was 485 miles (780 km) southeast of Charleston and packing maximum sustained winds of about 115 mph (185 kph).
Karlovich said if the storm progress further up the East Coast the refinery will take the necessary precautions, which include securing equipment.
Bud Davis, spokesman for Sun Co. Inc., said officials at company refineries in Philadelphia, PA, (307,000 bpd) and Marcus Hook, N.J. (175,000), were also eyeing the hurricane.
"We will be evaluating the storm situation and if it is likely to be heading this way we will take action," said Davis.
Officials at Coastal Corp's 130,000 bpd Eagle Point, N.J., refinery were also wary of Hurricane Fran's possible approach but have taken no precautionary measures.
"We are just watching it for now," said spokesman Brian Mitchell.
Earlier Wednesday, a hurricane watch for the U.S. East Coast had been extended northward to include from Sebastian Inlet, Fla, to Oregon Inlet, N.C.
A hurricane warning, indicating that hurricane conditions were expected within 24 hours, was likely to be issued Wednesday evening for a portion of the region, the National Hurricane Center said.
-- Laney Salisbury, New York Energy Desk, +1 212 859 1620
